question.body: Pyloric stenosis can be a congenital disease that results from the muscles of the pyloric valve being thicker than normal. As a result the opening between the stomach and the small intestine is narrowed and food cannot pass into the small intestine. How should the muscles of the pyloric valve contribute to proper digestive system?

multiple_choice.choice: Control the release of digestive enzymes from the small intestine
Churning the food and digestive juices in the stomach
Preventing food from ever exiting the stomach.

response.feedback: Incorrect. The sphincters control the release of food from the stomach.
Incorrect. The smooth muscles of the stomach churn the food. The sphincters are more like “gates”.
Incorrect. Food must exit the stomach to be absorbed for nutrients.
Correct. The sphincters provide “gates” that compartmentalize the digestive organs and processes.

part.hint: When it is narrowed food cannot pass and the child will vomit up food and fail to gain weight.
